results.title: Possessions (TEFC)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Ways of seeing”.
One of a series of films by the distinguished art critic and author, John Berger, in which he explores the ways in which we look at pictures. Berger argues that paintings were, and still are, the most valuable single objects which we can possess.

results.title: Possessions
results.creator_credit: Michael Dibb and TAFE National Video Resource Centre (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Ways of seeing”.
One of a series of films by art critic and author John Berger, which explores the ways in which we look at pictures. John Berger believes we have misunderstood the real meaning of European oil painting because we are normally encouraged to look at only a few exceptional works instead of the hundreds of thousands of unremakable pictures which make up the main tradition. He argues that this still continues today in the modern medium of advertising and publicity.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Michael Dibb and TAFE National Video Resource Centre (Australia)

results.title: Possessed
results.brief_description: Marion, a factory worker from Pennsylvania, has a glimpse of the high life and goes to New York to find such a life for herself. Marian is a quick learner and it is not long before she becomes mistress of a rich prominent lawyer, Mark Whitney. “Possessed” is a fascinating, trenchant drama with a strong screenplay based on the play “The mirage” by Edgar Selwyn. Stars Joan Crawford and Clark Cable.

results.title: Positioning for Function Workshop
results.brief_description: Seating and positioning for handicapped clients is thoroughly examined in this video and careful attention is given to designing equipment which meets, as fully as is possible, the individual needs. Such attention to design assists in maximising function.

results.title: Portugal
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “March of Time”.
A general picture of the Republic of Portugal. Presents Portugal as an example of Catholic social and economic policy. Shows the corporate organization of its society, under dictator Salazar. Gives glimpses of Portugal’s chief exports (Port wine, cork) and its fishing and farming - the greater part of the economy. Shows the education system, which is geared to social stability and respect for the past.

results.title: Ports of industrial Scandinava
results.brief_description: A journey down the east coast of Sweden by tramp steamer through the Gulf of Bothnia to the Baltic Sea with stops at various ports to unload cargo. It is winter and because the Gulf is not very salty is freezes easily. Lumber products are an important export. The trees are cut chiefly in winter by men who are frequently farmers in summer. Logs are bought to the pulp mills and the process of making wood pulp is shown. Steel and iron products are important exports from a region where iron mines and water power are abundant. Stockholm is the last stop and the home port, and we are shown something of the city, including the home surroundings of the first mate of the ship who goes ashore for a visit to his family.

results.title: Portraits: people with epilepsy
results.creator_credit: Donna Graham, Epilepsy Queensland and Samantha Shepherd
results.brief_description: Five people from different walks of life talk about their experience with epilepsy. Hugo Weaving tells of how it affects/doesn’t affect his work as an actor. Retiree Jean reflects on her life as an epileptic mother. Chef Ian addresses how he adapts his work in a stressful job to accommodate his condition. Uni student Sally talks about what it was like to study, then travel overseas, and primary school teacher Amanda explains how her students cope in the classroom. The five talk candidly about their achievements and how epilepsy has affected their lives. Funded by the Health Advancement Branch of Queensland Health and produced for Epilepsy Queensland.

results.title: Portraits: New England Fishermen
results.creator_credit: Contemporary Art Television (CAT) Fund and Joan Logue
results.brief_description: Presented with a straightforward charm, Logue’s abbreviated portraits of fishermen in Gloucester, Massachusetts are more than mere “fish stories”. Seen on their boats in the open sea, the fishermen speak directly to the camera, relating anecdotes and observations that are alternately comic or poignant. Logue documents the fishermen’s individual characters and evokes a sense of their rituals and traditions. With humor and pride, the fishermen chronicle their close ties to family, the ocean, and their community. Logue applies elegant video effects that heighten the resonance of these brief vignettes.
